title: How many total cases of COVID-19 in the U.S. will The COVID Tracking Project report as of Sunday 19 April 2020?
preds: At 722.2k currently, 8:30pm PT 18 Apr 2020. An increase of 27.7k / 4% over yesterday. A bit below both linear and exponential trends over the past week. To break 750k we would now need 27.8k / 3.9%. Hard to say at this point; it will be very close to the boundary. I wondered if reporting slows down on the weekend in some places, leading to an overall slowdown, but looking at the last 10 days of data does not show that in any obvious way.

In the end, it has become a much harder question. On one hand, on April 18th, 29 days have passed since the U.S. begun quarantines, which covers 98% of incubations. This suggests that the trend should be to decrease positive cases. On the other hand, the number of daily test results shows some spikes that seem to correlate lightly to spikes on the daily positive increase. Wich could suggest an increase in tomorrow's results due to an increase in testing. Finally, other countries have shown a similar reductive pattern like the U.S. Which also suggests a decrease in tomorrow's results.  I will be more comfortable narrowing the probability range to 90% between 740,000 and 760,000.
Wow. So close... with an average of 29k new positive over the last 3 days, we'll be hitting ~750100 give or take 1000.

My forecast is made on the actual number of cases.  This might not match the numbers published on the COVID tracker website because this site is not updated very reliably.  There are a number of problems with this challenge.... 1, the covid tracker has a cutoff at 1600 each day but this is not a good time because it is very variable what states release their test data before and after this time.
2, Sunday is NOT a good day to end this challenge because the testing data is not as reliably submitted over the weekend as during the week. Can I make a few suggestions? 1, Use the worldometer coronavirus tracker instead (it is updated more reliably)
2, Use a cutoff time of 2300.  By this time most results for the day are recorded
3, Use a cutoff day for these challenges during the week because they do not suffer from the 'lack of admin at weekend' problem.  Later in the week is better than earlier because early in the week the numbers include some but not all the weekend positive test results.   I am not trying to make the challenge easier but at present we are forecasting what number might be published on the covid tracker site not how many cases there are.  There is a subtle but important difference.  Most people on here would prefer to be forecasting the actual number of cases they expect not just trying to second guess what data may or may not be included on a given day.
Less than 24 hours left, estimating about 30-40k increase in cases per day at this point, unlikely to exceed 750k in next 24

My assumption is that numbers will come in pretty close to 750,000, and could plausibly be either on the high or low side of that, depending on how much test numbers fall this weekend. I have one percent for the 800-900K outcomes because of the possibility that some backlogged results may still be coming in-- I'm not sure the pending # on covidtracking.com covers the actual number of outstanding tests.

[EDIT] This is kinda messed up. COVID Project did not delay their 4PM count to wait for late reporters (which they say they might choose to do on their website). They CHANGED the number by around 8K AFTER reporting it.  We should use a more reliable and professional source for the COVID questions, like Our World In Data. https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus, which gets their numbers from the EU. This change made most of my commentary below pointless. Another comment on the question. This is a frustrating question because of the format. It would have been easy from the beginning to project with 90% + certainty a narrow band that included the correct outcome. Picking from the fixed bins made this much harder, and also less useful as an exercise. In the real world you would make a point forecast with error bands most of the time. So why did I change my estimate after yesterday's very low new case figure, which argues strongly for under 750,000?  One reason is that yesterday was misleading. NY didn't get its estimate into the Covid Project estimate and it usually does.  It will be in today's estimate instead, and if they report today's figure early tomorrow, there will be 3 NY estimates in the count for the last 2 days. That would add 7K to the final result offsetting yesterday's low number. The other reason is that, in general, Worldometer is a leading indicator for Covid Project, since it doesn't cut off around 4PM. Worldometer's daily count is higher for yesterday is higher than any other day since April 9. This means that even though today is a Saturday, it WILL be a big day, because Covid Project's estimate had yesterday as one of the lowest recent estimates. They have a lot of ground to make up. Their total after today will be at least 720,000. Leaving only 30K for Sunday. In the end, it will come down to the Sunday count. I still expect Sunday to be light based on day-of-week  cyclicality, but it's much less certain than the numbers suggest today. And finally, I decided to try to make a "good" prediction rather than a winning prediction. Trying to guess the right answer develops bad habits so it defeats the purpose of the project.

The numbers from the 8th Apr are simlar to the Total Cases chart from here 
https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/us/
We observe a roughly 1.04 increase daily, and extrapolating the numbers to the 19th gives us ~770k cases.
As of the 18th the figure is 696622. To be ≤ 700,000 would be an increase of just 3378. For it to be over 750,000 would be an increase of 53,378. On the current figures both are very unlikely.

After another day of 31 000 cases, meaning the last five days all have about 30 000 a day would lead to above 750 000 cases. While currently we require 27 740 each day for the last two days. There is 5 days ago that such a low number occurred. While if another day of 30 000 cases a day come the last one would require only 24 000, a day with such low numbers is even longer ago. It is therefore clear that it is highly likely, but not definite that it will breach the 750 000 cases a day.
It could be close, would call it at about 760K  -  maybe an adjustment later

Updating from 0/43/47/10/0/0/0/0 after today's growth rate was ~4.7%. Here are the daily growth rates we need (for each of the next 2 days) to break into each bucket: [700k, 750k] -- 0.4%
(750k, 800k) -- 3.9%
[800k, 850k] -- 7.3%
(850k, 900k) -- 10.6%
[900k, 950k] -- 13.8%
(950k, 1M) -- 17.0%
[1M, ∞ ) -- 20.0% The daily growth rates for each day of the past week, starting today and going backwards, have been: 4.7%, 4.8%, 5.0%, 4.5%, 4.5%, 5.5%, 6.0%. So I bring [800k, 850k] down from 10% to 2%. Seems all but impossible now that the next two days in a row will be >7% growth. The uncertainty here is coming from the "human dimension": measurement issues, unknown backlogs, etc --- not from the numbers. Now even if we assume linear growth, we'd need < 27.8k / day to not break 750k. Absolute growth this low has only happened twice in the last 2 weeks, or 1/7 chance. To get it two days in a row is a 2% chance. And I don't think growth looks linear quite yet. To get a little more quantitative, if we fit a linear function to the past 7 days on WolframAlpha [1], we get a daily growth of ~28.3k/day as the best fit and a prediction of 751.2k for 19 April. And if we fit an exponential function on those 7 days, we get a prediction of 762.9k for 19 April [2]. (Btw, the exponential fit is better: R^2 is 0.998 for linear, and 0.999995 for exponential.) Again due to "human dimension" uncertainties I'm not going to go like 90% in the (750k,800k) bucket. But ~75% does seem justified. [1] https://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=fit+linear+%281%2C+522843%29%2C+%282%2C+551826%29%2C+%283%2C+576774%29%2C+%284%2C+602473%29%2C+%285%2C+632656%29%2C+%286%2C+663260%29%2C+%287%2C+694520%29
[2] https://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=fit+exponential+%281%2C+522843%29%2C+%282%2C+551826%29%2C+%283%2C+576774%29%2C+%284%2C+602473%29%2C+%285%2C+632656%29%2C+%286%2C+663260%29%2C+%287%2C+694520%29
Man, it is right at the boundary!
Dang!... got busy for 2 days and couldn't stay abreast...  and now I'm way behind... Mr Brier, I hate you.

Shouldn't have lost my nerve last night.

New total cases 686,914. 
Looks like most of NY state missed today's count, so the US total was probably a good deal higher than recorded. We could get two NY state counts in tomorrow's data, which would make for a big day.
OTOH, the overall trend downward in pct positive test results seems to be outpacing the growth in tests - on average. Whether that will hold for the remainder of this question is up in the air.
daily update from figures half way through the day.  My current estimate is approx 754K but more likely to be higher than lower than this.
630k at the time of writing.  Cases rising by 25k (approx) each day. 2 days left.
741-765. Remains a nail-biter. I have more confidence in the higher end of my forecast, plus the centerpoint is above 750.
Losing my nerve waiting for a sat sun drop in positive tests.
Getting too close to call. My estimate is now 745-775 after an earlier forecast below 750, so I am having to hedge upwards to compensate. This will go to the wire I think!
with only 3 days to go I cannot see the situation changing sufficiently for the total to stay below 750K

Sunday reporting is always lower. 
Sunday 5th - 25,000. Down from 33,000 - Saturday the 4th and a 7 day low in testing.  Sunday 12th - 27 thousand, down from a high on Friday of 33700 (consider the good Friday).  The last 2 Sunday’s there has been a drop of 5000 from high and the Sunday figure has represented a week low. There is also a drop off on a Monday which represents a drop at the weekend.  New cases are steady at 29000. 
29x2(+22) = 80,000 + 667290 = 749000 It’s going to be close but I still lean under 750

Updating from 0/40/40/20/0/0/0/0 after today's growth rate was ~4.9%. Here are the daily growth rates we need (for each of the next 3 days) to break into each bucket: [700k, 750k] -- 1.8%
(750k, 800k) -- 4.2%
[800k, 850k] -- 6.4%
(850k, 900k) -- 8.6%
[900k, 950k] -- 10.7%
(950k, 1M) -- 12.7%
[1M, ∞ ) -- 14.7% Daily growth rates have been in the 4.5%--5.5%  range in the past 5 days, and not monotonically decreasing or increasing. So I take 10% away from [800k,850k] and split it into [700k, 750k] and (750k,800k). It's going to be pretty close to the boundary at 750k but for now it looks like it'll go over so I then move another couple %.
As of 16 April, with doubling at 11 days, expect about 60k new cases per day for next three days.  Arithmetical method for exponential function, but may work on a short time frame.

on the other hand....
today's official numbers came in higher than expected, and higher than worldometer.
737 - 768 range of estimates. Needs to be above 29k/day. It's a nail biter.
750k is really close to what will be the outcome. But because the end date is a sunday, <750 is more plausible imo. Updating prediction daily, and even hourly might be necessary.

US cases are increasing around 27000 per day. At this time there appears to be no slow down to those reported numbers. Cases still increasing over 30000 per day. As of 2 AM  https://covid19.who.int/region/amro/country/us

New cases should pass 750,000 as increased numbers come from states other than New York and as testing increases.  Sundays are under reported due to monitoring and testing decreases at week end with a linear trend at 750000+/- 20000.  This is a hedge to my previous forecast.

The last two days have seen elevated cases.

Well, it seems this will be close. Testing does not seem to be influenced by the weekend so a lot will depend if we can see actual reductions in cases in the coming days. Assuming that there are still a large number of unreported/undected/unknown cases, the 750,000 < x < 800,000 bracket does not seem out of reach. More tests mean more Covid-19 infected people will actually be tested and appear in the statistics.
It doesn't look like we will see the kind of numbers today that would push this above 750,000 by Sunday.
Adjusting for the bump in new cases, monotonic it is not. Test more, get more.

Given the numbers of current cases in the US, as reported by the NYTimes, as of the time of this estimate, and the fact that the daily new confirmed cases has begun to stabilize, 700-750 thousand seems most likely. Less than that seems very unlikely. There is, however, a possibility that the infection rate climbs once again.

There are currently 644,348 cases as of 16 April 2020. There's an average of 30K cases per day, so about 150-180 new cases by the 19 APRIL. I estimate 120-150K new cases taking the total to 764K to 795K

Hattip to @pietrokc for comment which prompted I for an update. The latest (15 April) daily cases increased by more than 5k than the day before.  The average daily cases for the last 5 days (since the peak) is 28k.  Add this to the next 4 days results in 744k, a bit higher than my original 725k but much closer to the boundary of 750k.  Adjust my forecast accordingly.

On 15 April 2020 we are at 632,656. Here are the daily growth rates we need to reach each bucket: 0: already there
1: 2.6%
2: 4.4%
3: 6.0%
4: 7.7%
5: 9.2%
6: 10.7%
7: 12.1% I computed the daily growth rates for the last 30 days and I would roughly categorize them as follows: 17 March -- 28 March
Wildly fluctuating between 20% and 40% a day. Seems clear that tests were still rolling out. Lots of noise. Big growth but trending downward over this period. 29 March -- 04 April
Growth trending steadily downward from ~16% to ~12%. 05 April -- 10 April
Daily growth kind of constant around 8%. 11 April -- 15 April
Growth trending downward from ~6% to ~4.5%. Specifically, there are sizeable jumps at the boundaries I chose, could be noise, or could be (2 weeks after) when various places went into lockdown. For instance, NY went into lockdown on 20 March, that plus two weeks is 3 April, near the second breakpoint. About a week ago, 95% of Americans were under some kind of lockdown [1]. So I think that for the next 4 days we will not see a big surprise jump up in daily growth. So I am comfortable ruling out buckets 4-7. On the other hand daily growth is not going to halve in the next 4 days either, so I rule out bucket 0. The (log-)average daily growth in last 5 days (last period) is 5%, so bucket 2 seems most likely, as 4 days is not very long. But the result will be closer to the 1/2 boundary than the 2/3 boundary. I feel ~20% for bucket 3 and even split for buckets 1/2 is about right. [1] https://www.businessinsider.com/us-map-stay-at-home-orders-lockdowns-2020-3

Current total (official) is 632,656. 
Delta = 750,000 - 632,656 = 117,344, or an average of 29,336 for each of the remaining 4 days.

The new cases yesterday (14 April) has increased again.  not by much but enough to make me believe that the downward trend may not be strong.  This could be late reporting from the Easter break so I am only increasing the probability that the total might fall into the 750-800 bracket.
number of new cases decreasing day by day
In the last couple days, the daily infected cases are ~25k per day.  Add this to the next 5 days results in ~725k cases.

This one is tough, with a straight line projection coming in very close to 750,000.  I think it will come in just under as testing seems fairly stagnant right now. NY has the 1/6 of all tests performed and their positive rate is dropping. That argues for a lower count. OTOH, NJ could offset that if it ramps up testing. Right now 50% of NJ tests are positive. However, the number of tests they're running hasn't increased in two weeks.  Could it get above 800,000? That would take an increase of about 12K per day for the last four days. Very unlikely unless we're still seeing a post-Easter reporting delay and there's a big backlog coming.

Considering that 98% of the COVID-19 incubation period ranges from 2 to 21 days and that US states ordered stay at home measures between 16th and 20th of March. On April 4th the 14 days incubation period cases should begin to show a reduction in an exponential increase. On April 10th, the 21 days incubation cases should be covered (98% of cases). Also, Google shows a decrease in about 47% of mobility since US states ordered stay at home, which suggests that some transmission will continue to take place but there is a 53% probability that superspreading events stop. Therefore, reducing the number of cases. Other countries show a pattern of some days with a similar number of cases before the number begins falling. If this pattern repeats in the US, the number of cases shouldn't change importantly between 3 to 6 days.
My model is behaving quite stable for quite a while. Shouldn't change within the time left. If not, I may run for cover.
The positive cases of covid-19 are increasing about 25.000 per day. The media of tests per day isen't changing. So, in five days, the positive cases will reach at 700.000 or so.

The diference between one day and the next is about 25 cases positives. The number of tests are not increasing. The number today is 602.473. So, if nothing change extremaly, the number of positives will not reach more than 700.000.

Hattip to @bobrown on alerting me that the inflection point for infected cases has already arrived on 11 April.  Using this date, instead of 16 April in my previous forecast, results in 706k by 19 April.

Taking into account that the US has been testing about 150,000 people/day (and increasing) and positive rates have been about 20% (as high as 40% in NYC), then in four days from now I expect we'll add about 120,000 to the current tally of 580,000, erring on the higher side.
Current cases + trended development of new cases using development from other developed nations with similar self distancing measures but in an advanced position relative to the US
Correcting my error with updated forecast.

In april the numbers have varied between 35 and 25 thousand positive cases a day and with a reverse u shape becoming apparent, in the next 5 days there is therefore a chance that it will drop to a an average of 20000 a day or go up to 35 000 a day. Which my estimate attempt to show.

Extrapolating linearly gives around 705,000, and I suspect that daily confirmed cases will stay around constant from now on. I would be surprised if they decrease enough to lead to <700,000 in five days but it seems more likely than a rapid increase.
mistake in my first forecast, I hit submit before I was really ready!

The doubling rate has slowed considerably and the number of tests conducted has also slowed.  This sugests that the number of people presenting themselves to hospital has also slowed.  I therefore expect the number of transmissions to continue to slow. I expect the number to be around 705,000 but being close to the boundary of two bins makes it a difficult call

Today we have 580k confirmed cases. Daily increase is around 30k new cases. I expect the increase of new cases will not go beyond 30k per day. Sunday 19Th is 6 days to go, so confirmed cases should go to 750k - 800k

Using the logistic model with a turning point on 16 April (3 weeks from the start of an effective lockdown by analyzing the relative Workplaces mobility in the Google Mobility Reports [1]) results in 767k total infected cases on 19 April. The current doubling time is 9 days [2].  Extending this to the remaining 6 days results in 885k cases.  If the doubling time turns to 11 days in 3 days, and keeps it to the end, then the total cases will be 849k.  But both cases are less likely since the turning point is near. Similarly to what I did with the April 12th question [1] (with some minor modifications), I'm using a crude pseudo-model [2] that takes the average logistic (S-/sigmoid) curve of all countries (from ECDC via OurWorldInData.org [3]), starting from each country's first day of 100 cases, using current U.S. data from The COVID Tracking Project [4] to place it on the curve using the average of the last three days' growth rates, and projecting the curve from that point forward to April 19th. I then average the last three days of April 19th projections to establish a my official mean count. I do this to smooth out potential growth rate volatility from one day to the next. To find the probabilities for each bin, I then set a max upward bound of the difference of the projected mean and the latest count. For example, yesterday's projection shows a mean of 777,632 U.S. cases by April 19th. After subtracting today's count 551,826) and adding to the mean, the upper bound then is 1,003,437 cases. Upper and lower bounds should be ~4 standard deviations (covering 99.994% [5] of the normal distribution). I make a small adjustment to the upper bound to expand it based on the variance between the last three days of projection to account for amount of uncertainty. Because I'm taking the difference between projected mean and today's count, this standard deviation will naturally narrow as we get closer to the forecast close date, honing in on a particular bin. I then calculate probabilities for bins based on the mean and those standard deviations. I'll update my model and forecast daily. Current forecasts:

4/19/2020: 754,995 Average mean (projections for 4/19 over last three days): 777,632

Exponential growth and the speed of it

Reasons for lower number:
- growth rate has been declining recently
- Lock down still in place
- significant increase in number of tests unlikely over next week
- even (partially) lifting the lock-down should not immediately lead to higher number as incubation period will lead to lag Reasons for higher number:
- the decline in growth over the last few days could be Easter related and could lead to increase in the coming week
- other countries have had a declining growth rate only to see it moving back higher
